sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To assess the feasibility of intracorporeal lithotripsy with holmium YAG laser under sialoendoscopic guidance for sialolithiasis of Wharton’s duct.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: Case series with planned data collection.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Tertiary referral university hospital.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study was conducted on 16 patients with sialolithiasis of Wharton’s duct. Diagnosis was confirmed at ultrasound examination. Patients with stones ranging from 5 to 8 mm in diameter were enrolled in the study. The selected patients underwent intracorporeal lithotripsy with holmium Yag laser under endoscopic control. Debris was removed using sialoendoscopic forceps or a wire basket during the same procedure. After a 3-month follow-up, radiological tests were rerun.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Stone fragmentation was possible in all cases. All patients experienced a regular postoperative course. Postoperative ultrasound examinations revealed residual stones in 3 patients, 1 of whom was asymptomatic. Three patients complained of residual symptoms after 3 months of follow-up. These patients were treated successfully during a second sialoendoscopic procedure.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In our experience, endoscopic laser lithotripsy was proved to be a feasible technique for Wharton’s duct lithiasis in clinical practice.

body.p: Salivary stones are one of the principal causes of chronic sialadenitis, are involved in 66% of cases, and account for approximately 50% of major salivary gland diseases.1 Classic symptoms of this condition are pain and swelling of the involved gland during eating due to excretory duct obstruction. Chronic obstruction of the ducts and subsequent infectious episodes result in salivary gland fibrosis. Escudier and McGurk2 described a clinical prevalence of 0.45% for obstructive calculi, which are more frequent in male patients with incidence peaks between 30 and 60 years of age. According to published data, salivary stones are localized in the submandibular gland in 80% to 90% of cases, mainly unilaterally and without a preferred side. Most calculi are located in the distal third of the duct or at the hilum of the gland; pure intraparenchymal stones are infrequent.3,4

Treatment of submandibular sialolithiasis has radically changed with the diffusion of sialoendoscopy during the past 2 decades.5 According to a well-known algorithm proposed by Marchal, sialoliths with a diameter smaller than 4 mm can be endoscopically removed with wire baskets, whereas stones with a diameter greater than 8 mm require a combined surgical and sialoendoscopic approach. According to this scheme, salivary stones measuring between the above-mentioned diameters must be fragmented to allow their passage through the narrow duct system.4,6 The fragmentation of sialoliths can be achieved either by extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) or by using endoductal techniques with the aid of electrohydraulic, pneumoblastic, or laser devices.7

Endoscopically guided intracorporeal laser lithotripsy was first described in the early 1990s with satisfactory results. Nevertheless, in subsequent literature, there are only occasional small case series concerning the use of different kinds of lasers, without uniqueness in outcomes.7 This study reports the results obtained using the holmium yttrium-aluminum-garnet (Ho:YAG) laser under sialoendoscopic guidance in 16 patients affected by Wharton’s duct sialolithiasis.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: With approval of the Review Board on Biomedical Research of the Department of Surgical Biotechnologies and Science of the “Sapienza” University of Rome, 16 patients (7 men, 9 women) affected by unilateral submandibular sialolithiasis with 5- to 8-mm stone diameters were enrolled in this prospective study from June 2010 to February 2012. The average age of the patients was 47 ± 7 years. The average stone size was 6.5 ± 0.7 mm. They were located in the right submandibular duct in 9 cases and in the left in 7.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: A flow chart describing the study design is illustrated in Figure 1. All of the patients enrolled in the study complained of 2 or more episodes of unilateral submandibular gland swelling accompanied by pain, with or without pus or jellylike fluid discharging from the orifice of the duct. After an accurate evaluation of clinical history, the patients underwent a general ear, nose, and throat (ENT) examination, and then ultrasound evaluation confirmed the diagnostic suspicion of submandibular sialolithiasis in all cases by ultrasound examination. Ultrasonography detected the number, position, and maximum diameter of salivary stones. Patients with multiple or intraparenchymal stones or with sialoliths less than 5 mm or greater than 8 mm in diameter were excluded from this study. All the selected patients underwent intracorporeal lithotripsy with Ho:Yag laser under sialoendoscopic control and general anesthesia. Before surgery, clinicians thoroughly informed patients about the risks associated with the off-label use of this medical device, designed for fragmentation of urinary calculi, and recorded the informed consent. Patients were also informed that the procedure may not be resolutory and that treatment would be converted into a combined approach or into a classic sialectomy in case the lithotripsy failed. All sialoendoscopies were performed by a surgical team of 4 surgeons (A.G., G.P, S.M, C.G). At the end of each procedure, the patients were encouraged to follow a normal diet to restore salivary flow as soon as possible. All cases were reevaluated and recorded 6 days after the procedure. This clinical follow-up was planned in order to detect any residual swelling of submandibular glands and/or of the mouth floor. Only inspection and palpation of the surgical field and submandibular gland were performed. Moreover, any signs or symptoms reported by the patients were collected, including postoperative pain or discomfort. Three months after surgery, all patients were reevaluated and an ultrasound examination was rerun to detect the presence of any residual sialoliths. Additional sialoendoscopy was proposed for patients complaining of residual symptoms after 3 months, with or without evidence of residual stones at ultrasound examination. Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS for Windows version 15.0 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, Illinois).

sec.title: Surgical Technique
sec.p: The procedure was performed under general anesthesia using all-in-one sialoendoscopes with an external diameter of 1.6 mm (Karl Storz GmbH, Tuttlingen, Germany), maintaining constant irrigation with saline to improve visibility. When the impacted sialolith appeared on the monitor, the laser fiber was introduced into the working channel of the endoscope. Intraoperative lithotripsy was performed using a Ho:YAG laser with 200 µm fibers (Dornier Medilas H20, Germering, Germany). The tip of the fiber was positioned at an incident angle of 90° at the center of the stone. The Ho:YAG laser was then activated with the following settings: 2.5 to 3.5 W at 5 Hz/s, 50 to 80 mJ (Figure 2; Video 1, available at otojournal.org). The laser was used under clear vision and tangentially to the duct, avoiding contact with the ductal wall. After fragmentation, debris of the stones was removed using wire baskets or microforctif. Betamethasone 12 mg/10 mL was injected into the gland through the endoscope at the end of every procedure, and a polyethylene sialostent (diameter: 2 mm, length: 45 mm; Ad-Tech-Med Ltd, Lublin, Poland) was inserted into the Wharton’s duct and held in place for 2 weeks. During the procedure, antibiotics and steroids were not used intravenously.

caption.p: Intracorporeal lithotripsy with Ho:YAG laser under sialoendoscopic guidance. Intraoperative picture.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Stone fragmentation under sialoendoscopic guidance was accomplished in all cases. Immediately after surgery, the submandibular region appeared swollen in all patients, but in all cases the return to a normal aspect was achieved within 48 hours from the procedure. All 16 patients experienced a regular postoperative course during the first week without complications in terms of bleeding or nerve damage. Three patients (18.75%) complained of persistent obstructive symptoms (meaning 1 or more episodes of submandibular swelling with or without pain) 90 days after surgery. Ultrasonographic evaluation showed residual salivary stones in 3 patients (18.75%), 2 of which (12.5%) reported the persistence of obstructive symptoms, whereas the remaining patient was asymptomatic. Therefore, a second sialoendoscopy was proposed for the 3 symptomatic patients, only 2 of whom showed evidence of residual sialolithiasis at ultrasonography. The 2 patients with residual stones underwent sialoendoscopy under local anesthesia, and the remaining debris was removed using a wire basket.

The second sialoendoscopy performed on the single patient without evidence of salivary stones revealed a tight stenosis extending for approximately 5 mm in correspondence to the distal third of Wharton’s duct, which was previously the site of the salivary stone. The stricture was treated by irrigating the duct with sustained force and performing several dilations with a sialoballoon. A sialostent was inserted into the duct at the end of the procedure and was then guided with the endoscope until the tip passed the stricture. After 3 months of additional follow-up, all retreated patients were symptom free.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Lithotripsy is a minimally invasive approach for removal of salivary stones that are too large to be entirely extracted from the ducts, thus avoiding transoral sialolithectomy or external sialoadenectomy in most cases.8

ESWL of salivary calculi was introduced to clinical practice by Iro et al9 in 1989. Innovative, dedicated lithotripters with a mobile arm have helped improve results to the point at which they have become the main established technique for stone fragmentation for the past decade.9-14

ESWL usually requires several sessions at intervals of a few weeks. The stones, once fragmented, are expected to be evacuated spontaneously or are retrieved by Dormia baskets under endoscopic control.15 However, many authors reported a low success rate for this technique ranging from 32% to 42% for submandibular stones. Furthermore, the use of shock waves causes some side effects such as damage to salivary glands with bleeding, corruption of dental amalgams, and hearing impairments.10-13

Residual lithiasis of the submandibular gland has been reported in 40% to 50% of cases and probably represents the main limitation of ESWL. In fact, stone fragments left inside the duct system may subsequently become the nidus for further calcification and sialolithiasis recurrence.6,7 It should be emphasized that ESWL eliminates a greater proportion of parotid calculi than submandibular calculi, and, consequently, the risk of recurrence after ESWL is higher for sialolithiasis of Wharton’s duct.16

Intracorporeal lithotripsy represents an alternative to ESWL. In the literature, several endoductal techniques have been proposed for intracorporeal lithotripsy based on electrohydraulic, pneumoblastic, or laser energy.17-21 Among these, the first two have almost been abandoned because of their low efficacy and reported injuries to the canal wall.6-8

Endoscopic laser lithotripsy was adopted from the urological practice, having been widely used as treatment for urinary calculi since the 1980s with acknowledged efficacy.22 In the ENT field, Gundlach et al21 firstly performed a preliminary in vitro study to examine the use of a laser beam in salivary stone fragmentation prior to treating 12 patients suffering from sialolithiasis of the submandibular gland, using a pulsed excimer laser with a 92% success rate.

Contrary to what happened to the urinary tract, laser lithotripsy for salivary glands has never been widely used, and the experience reported in the literature has been conducted in vitro or on a limited number case series.18,21,23-30 Currently, there is no consensus as to which laser is the most appropriate in achieving safe and effective lithotripsy for salivary glands, but the main qualities and defects of the various lasers tested are known.

The dye laser has shown efficacy and low morbidity, as the high energy delivered is not absorbed by the tissues.24 Unfortunately, its high cost and specificity for salivary stones make it unaffordable for a single referral center, thus preventing the diffusion of this promising technique for intraductal lithotripsy.6,7

The use of holmium and the erbium YAG for urinary stone fragmentation is widely reported in the medical literature and is usually associated with a low rate of complications.22 The holmium-YAG laser is a pulsed, solid-state laser that produces light at a wavelength of 2.1 µm in the near-infrared region. It is compatible with a conventional silica fiber, making it suitable for both endoscopic and percutaneous use. It also has a high absorption coefficient in water (3 mm−1), suggesting a safety advantage if used in an aqueous environment such as saliva.31 However, the reduced size of the salivary ducts revealed some side effects associated with the use of this device, which is related to the risk of soft-tissue damage attributable both to its thermal effects and absorption by the surrounding tissues.6,7,26

In our series, the use of the Ho:YAG laser as a lithotripter showed excellent results, achieving fragmentation of the sialoliths in all cases. Full success of the procedure, definable as complete relief of symptoms with absence of residual stones at ultrasonography, was achieved in 12 of 16 patients (75%) at follow-up 3 months after surgery.

The possibility of splitting the stone and retrieving its fragments immediately after lithotripsy represents, in our opinion, the most relevant advantage of this endoductal technique if compared with ESWL. As reported above, debris left in the ductal system and not cleared by salivary flow can lead to the formation of other stones. In our study, the persistence of sialoliths 3 months after the procedure has been detected in 3 patients. It is therefore likely that in these cases, some residual fragments that were not retrieved from the duct have again reached dimensions large enough to cause duct reobstruction, fusing together and/or favoring the deposition of additional inorganic matrix. These cases of recurrence were treated effectively by repeating sialoendoscopy under local anesthesia.

A second sialoendoscopic procedure 3 months after lithotripsy was also required for a single patient who complained of symptom recurrence despite ultrasound evaluation and absence of calculi. The localized stenosis diagnosed in this case was probably a consequence of a repair process of Wharton’s duct in response to possible thermal damage caused by the activation of the laser in contact with the ductal wall. However, stenosis may be the result of a trauma caused by contact between the stone itself and the ductal epithelium. Even in this case, the obstruction was treated endoscopically with satisfactory outcomes.

To avoid injuries of the ductal wall, as suggested by Marchal, the laser should be activated only under clear vision, tangential to the duct, at the center of the stone, and almost adjacent to its surface.6 Moreover, laser energy has to be discharged only to make the stone smaller to allow its removal endoscopically, without aiming to grind the sialoliths. It may be deduced that a limited use of laser can reduce the frequency of complications.

The injection of steroid solution into the ducts at the end of the procedure aims at reducing the inflammatory response to the ductal wall to laser activation, therefore limiting stenosis and ductal fibrosis. This maneuver, as well as sialostent positioning to maintain the patency of the duct, helps reduce the risk of stenosis.32

Although few series on laser lithotripsy of salivary stones have been described in the medical literature, Raif et al25 suggested the potential advantages of erbium Yag laser over holmium. Our experience supports the positive outcomes reported by some authors in obtaining fragmentation of salivary stones by means of holmium Yag laser. The similar and comparable results of both kinds of laser represent a finding of paramount importance nowadays because of limited financial resources. In fact, most hospitals are already equipped with one of these lasers for urinary stone fragmentation, and therefore the purchase of a new laser for salivary stones is not required. Expensive medical devices dedicated to external or internal lithotripsy may represent an economic burden for a single institution because of the low incidence of salivary stones requiring fragmentation. A multipractice use of a single medical instrument has clear economic advantages. The fragmentation of urinary stones with laser is a commonly performed procedure in most multipractice general hospitals. The use of a Ho:YAG laser for both urinary and salivary stones may therefore represent a good solution, and this prompted our choice in addition to the theoretical clinical advantage of such devices.

Our preliminary results, although promising, are based on limited experience but did confirm the feasibility of this technique. Nevertheless, further studies based on the comparison between ESWL and laser lithotripsy and with a longer follow-up are necessary to confirm that Ho:Yag laser is the standard of treatment for large lithiasis of Wharton’s duct.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In our experience, lithotripsy with Ho:YAG laser is a feasible and cost-effective technique for the treatment of sialolithiasis of Wharton’s duct, enabling the avoidance of most more invasive approaches. Nevertheless, other studies on this promising technique are necessary to prove that laser lithotripsy should be preferred to other treatment options.
